items.description: Analyze repository structure and define project scope for the minimal gravity simulator
items.acceptance_criteria: A document (PROJECT_SCOPE.md) listing all existing repo files, the chosen programming language (Python), target capabilities (2D/3D N-body gravitational simulation), and a module map showing planned source files and their responsibilities
items.notes: PROJECT_SCOPE.md created with repo file listing, Python as language, 2D/3D N-body capabilities, and full module map

items.description: Conduct literature review on N-body gravitational simulation methods using web search
items.acceptance_criteria: A written summary (literature_review.md) covering at least: (1) direct-summation methods, (2) symplectic integrators (leapfrog, Verlet), (3) tree-based methods (Barnes-Hut), (4) softening techniques, and (5) adaptive time-stepping. Must cite at least 10 papers by author and year
items.notes: literature_review.md created with 5 sections covering all required topics, citing 15 papers by author and year

items.description: Survey existing open-source N-body simulation codebases via web search
items.acceptance_criteria: A summary of at least 5 open-source N-body projects (e.g., REBOUND, Gadget, NBODY6, AstroSim) noting their language, integrator choices, force algorithms, and licensing. Documented in literature_review.md or a separate survey section
items.notes: Survey of 6 open-source projects (REBOUND, GADGET-2, NBODY6, GravHopper, galpy, grav_sim) added to literature_review.md with comparison table

items.description: Create and populate sources.bib with BibTeX entries for all consulted references
items.acceptance_criteria: sources.bib exists in repo root with at least 10 valid BibTeX entries covering: Aarseth (gravitational N-body), Verlet (1967 integration), Barnes & Hut (1986 tree code), Wisdom & Holman (symplectic maps), Springel (Gadget), Rein & Liu (REBOUND), and at least 4 additional relevant references
items.notes: sources.bib populated with 20 BibTeX entries covering all required references plus additional ones

items.description: Formalize the mathematical formulation of the N-body gravitational problem
items.acceptance_criteria: A document (FORMULATION.md) containing: Newton's law of gravitation for N particles, equations of motion as a system of ODEs, definitions of total energy (kinetic + potential), total linear momentum, and total angular momentum as conserved quantities, with LaTeX-style notation
items.notes: FORMULATION.md created with Newton's law, ODEs, conserved quantities (E, P, L), Hamiltonian formulation, softening, and natural units

items.description: Compare numerical integration methods and select candidates for implementation
items.acceptance_criteria: A comparison table in FORMULATION.md listing Forward Euler, Leapfrog (Störmer-Verlet), Velocity Verlet, and RK4 with columns for: order of accuracy, symplecticity (yes/no), energy drift behavior, computational cost per step, and suitability for gravitational dynamics. Justified selection of at least 3 methods to implement
items.notes: Comparison table added to FORMULATION.md with all 4 methods and 7 properties. Selected Forward Euler, Leapfrog, and Velocity Verlet for implementation. RK4 excluded with justification.

items.description: Implement particle data structures and initialization routines
items.acceptance_criteria: A Python module (sim/body.py or similar) defining a Body/Particle class with mass, position (2D or 3D vector), and velocity attributes. An initialization function that can set up: (1) a two-body Kepler orbit, (2) a random N-body system. All code passes at least 3 unit tests verifying attribute storage and initialization correctness
items.notes: sim/body.py with kepler_circular, kepler_elliptical, random_system. 9 unit tests passing in tests/test_body.py

items.description: Implement direct-summation O(N^2) pairwise gravitational force computation
items.acceptance_criteria: A function computing gravitational acceleration on each particle via direct pairwise summation. Verified against hand-calculated values for a 2-body and 3-body configuration. At least 3 unit tests passing, including a test that confirms O(N^2) scaling by timing N=100 vs N=200
items.notes: sim/forces.py with direct_summation function. 6 unit tests passing including 2-body, 3-body, Newton 3rd law, O(N^2) scaling, and softening

items.description: Implement Forward Euler time integration as the baseline integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: A Forward Euler integrator that advances positions and velocities by one time step. Verified on a circular two-body orbit: orbit completes approximately one period with visible energy drift. At least 2 unit tests confirming position update correctness
items.notes: sim/integrators.py with euler function. 3 tests: position update, velocity update, energy drift on Kepler orbit

items.description: Implement energy and momentum conservation diagnostics
items.acceptance_criteria: Functions computing total kinetic energy, total gravitational potential energy, total linear momentum, and total angular momentum of the system. Verified against hand calculations for a 2-body system. At least 3 unit tests passing
items.notes: sim/diagnostics.py with kinetic_energy, potential_energy, total_energy, linear_momentum, angular_momentum. 6 tests passing including hand calculations and Kepler verification

items.description: Establish baseline benchmarks on a two-body Kepler orbit
items.acceptance_criteria: Run Forward Euler on a circular Kepler orbit for 1000 steps. Record: (1) relative energy error vs time, (2) wall-clock time. Save numerical results to results/baseline_euler.json. Energy error magnitude and growth rate documented
items.notes: Baseline: dt=0.01, 1000 steps (~1.6 orbits). Max |dE/E|=1.47e-1, growth rate=1.43e-2 per time unit. Wall time=0.027s. Results in results/baseline_euler.json

items.description: Implement symplectic Leapfrog (kick-drift-kick) integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: A Leapfrog/Störmer-Verlet integrator using the kick-drift-kick formulation. On the same circular Kepler orbit as item_011, energy error must remain bounded (no secular drift) over 10,000 steps. At least 2 unit tests passing. Energy error should be orders of magnitude better than Forward Euler
items.notes: Leapfrog KDK: bounded energy error 2.5e-9 over 10k steps (59M times better than Euler). 2 unit tests passing.

items.description: Implement Velocity Verlet integrator and compare with Leapfrog
items.acceptance_criteria: A Velocity Verlet integrator implemented and verified to produce identical trajectories to Leapfrog (to machine precision) on a test orbit. Documented equivalence in a comparison note. At least 2 unit tests passing

items.description: Implement gravitational softening to handle close encounters
items.acceptance_criteria: A configurable softening parameter epsilon added to the force computation (r^2 + eps^2 denominator). Demonstrated on a 3-body near-collision scenario: simulation completes without NaN/Inf. Analysis of softening parameter's effect on energy conservation at 3 different epsilon values saved to results/softening_analysis.json

items.description: Implement adaptive time-stepping for eccentric orbits
items.acceptance_criteria: An adaptive time-step scheme (e.g., based on acceleration magnitude or nearest-neighbor distance) that reduces dt during close approaches and increases dt during slow phases. Tested on an e=0.9 elliptical orbit: completes 10 orbits with bounded energy error and fewer total steps than fixed-dt. Results saved to results/adaptive_dt.json

items.description: Implement Barnes-Hut tree algorithm for O(N log N) force computation
items.acceptance_criteria: A Barnes-Hut octree (3D) or quadtree (2D) with configurable opening angle theta. Force accuracy within 1% of direct summation for theta=0.5 on a 500-particle random system. Timing demonstrates sub-quadratic scaling: wall time for N=1000 is less than 4x wall time for N=500. At least 3 unit tests passing

items.description: Energy conservation benchmark: compare all integrators over 10,000 steps
items.acceptance_criteria: Run Forward Euler, Leapfrog, and Velocity Verlet on a circular Kepler orbit for 10,000 steps with the same dt. Record max |dE/E| for each. Results saved to results/energy_benchmark.json. Leapfrog and Verlet must show bounded oscillating error; Euler must show secular drift. Results compared against expected convergence orders from literature (cite sources.bib)

items.description: Performance scaling benchmark: wall time vs N for direct and tree methods
items.acceptance_criteria: Measure wall-clock time for direct summation and Barnes-Hut at N = 64, 128, 256, 512, 1024 particles for a single force evaluation. Fit power-law exponents. Direct must show exponent ~2.0; Barnes-Hut must show exponent < 1.5. Results saved to results/scaling_benchmark.json

items.description: Test canonical gravitational scenarios: circular orbit, elliptical orbit, and figure-8 three-body
items.acceptance_criteria: Three test scenarios run successfully: (1) circular two-body orbit maintains radius within 1% over 100 orbits, (2) elliptical orbit (e=0.5) preserves eccentricity within 5% over 50 orbits, (3) figure-8 three-body choreography (Chenciner-Montgomery initial conditions) remains stable for at least 5 periods. Results saved to results/canonical_tests.json

items.description: Compare quantitative results against published literature values
items.acceptance_criteria: For each canonical scenario, compare obtained energy conservation and orbital elements against at least 2 published reference values from sources.bib. Discrepancies documented and explained. Comparison table saved to results/literature_comparison.md

items.description: Generate trajectory and energy-drift visualizations
items.acceptance_criteria: At least 4 publication-quality figures saved to figures/ as PNG: (1) 2-body orbit trajectory, (2) energy error vs time for all integrators, (3) scaling benchmark log-log plot, (4) figure-8 three-body trajectory. Each figure has axis labels, legend, and title

items.description: Create quantitative integrator comparison summary table
items.acceptance_criteria: A table (in results/integrator_summary.md) with columns: Integrator, Order, Symplectic, Max |dE/E| at 10k steps, Wall Time per Step, and Recommended Use Case. Covers all implemented integrators. Values drawn from experiments in Phase 4

items.description: Write FINDINGS.md with methodology, results, and conclusions
items.acceptance_criteria: FINDINGS.md in repo root with sections: (1) Introduction and problem statement, (2) Methods (integrators, force algorithms, softening, adaptive stepping), (3) Results (referencing figures/ and results/), (4) Discussion comparing against prior work cited in sources.bib, (5) Conclusions. At least 2000 words, citing at least 8 references from sources.bib

items.description: Document codebase with docstrings and usage instructions
items.acceptance_criteria: Every public function and class has a docstring describing purpose, parameters, and return value. A USAGE.md file explains how to run the simulator, run benchmarks, and generate figures with example command lines

items.description: Final README with project overview, results summary, and reproduction instructions
items.acceptance_criteria: README.md updated with: (1) project title and one-paragraph description, (2) key results (best energy conservation, scaling exponents), (3) repository structure listing, (4) installation and reproduction instructions (requirements.txt with dependencies, run commands), (5) references to FINDINGS.md and sources.bib
